questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes Emil Kraepelin’s classification of mental disorders?

options.label: A
options.text: Dementia praecox was characterized by a decline in cognitive function, while manic-depressive psychosis was characterized by fluctuations between depressive and manic episodes.

options.label: B
options.text: Dementia praecox referred to a cognitive decline in young individuals, while manic-depressive psychosis was exclusively seen in older adults.

options.label: C
options.text: Dementia praecox was an early term for bipolar disorder, while manic-depressive psychosis was an early term for schizophrenia.

options.label: D
options.text: Both dementia praecox and manic-depressive psychosis were characterized by psychosis, but dementia praecox was considered a more severe form.

questions.correct_answer: A. Dementia praecox was characterized by a decline in cognitive function, while manic-depressive psychosis was characterized by fluctuations between depressive and manic episodes.

Ans. A) Dementia praecox was characterized by a decline in cognitive function, while manic-depressive psychosis was characterized by fluctuations between depressive and manic episodes.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . This statement is incorrect because Kraepelin did not restrict dementia praecox to young individuals and manic-depressive psychosis to older adults . His classification was based on the type of symptoms and course of the illness rather than the age of onset.
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • incorrect
  • • Kraepelin did not restrict dementia praecox to young individuals and manic-depressive psychosis to older adults
  • • Option C . This statement reverses the modern terms for the disorders Kraepelin described . Dementia praecox is an early term for what is now known as schizophrenia, not bipolar disorder, and manic-depressive psychosis is an early term for what is now known as bipolar disorder, not schizophrenia.
  • • Option
  • • C
  • • reverses the modern terms for the disorders Kraepelin described
  • • Option D. While both conditions involved psychosis, Kraepelin did not characterize dementia praecox simply as a more severe form of psychosis. He distinguished the two based on symptomatology, course, and outcome, with dementia praecox having a more chronic and deteriorating course.
  • • Option

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese female patient with schizophrenia is currently being treated with risperidone. She has recently developed galactorrhea. What should be the next step in her treatment?

Switch to olanzapine: While olanzapine is a second-generation antipsychotic with a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia compared to risperidone , it is associated with a higher risk of weight gain and metabolic side effects . Given the patient's obesity, olanzapine may not be the best choice.

  • • higher risk of weight gain and metabolic side effects

  • • Option B. Switch to haloperidol:

  • • higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to second-generation antipsychotics
  • • Option C. Switch to amisulpride: Amisulpride is another second-generation antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia. Switching to amisulpride may not effectively address the patient's galactorrhea and could potentially exacerbate the issue.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the psychiatry clinic referred from dermatologist with severe distress over a persistent belief that she is infested with bugs. She reports feeling them crawl on and under her skin, especially at night, and has multiple self-inflicted excoriated lesions on her arms and legs from trying to "remove the bugs." She has seen multiple physicians, and all diagnostic evaluations, including skin biopsies, have returned negative for parasitic infestations. Her family is concerned about her increasing isolation, noting she has thrown out furniture and avoids family gatherings, fearing she might spread the "infestation." Despite evidence to the contrary, she firmly believes in the presence of the parasites and has even brought in small lint balls from her bed, claiming they are the bugs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The items are usually stored in a small container, like a matchbox). Treatment includes antipsychotic medications, like pimozide or risperidone. questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the psychiatric clinic accompanied by his 60-year-old father. The father reports increasing concern regarding his son's behavior over the past few months. He explains that his son has become increasingly suspicious of their neighbors, often voicing concerns that they are plotting against him. He spends hours peeking through curtains and has even set up cameras. What deeply worries the father, however, is that over the past six weeks, the patient's 25-year-old sister has begun exhibiting similar behavior. She now avoids the neighbors, claiming they are plotting against her as well. Both siblings previously had good relationships with these neighbors and there's no concrete evidence to support their beliefs. Which of the following terms best describes this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Folie à deux.

  • • Shared psychotic disorder is characterized by spread of delusions from one person to another . The individual who has the delusion (the primary case) is typically the influential member of a close relationship with a more suggestible person (the secondary case) who also develops the delusion. When two people are involved, the term “folie à deux” is used. Occasionally more than two individuals are involved (known as folie à trois, folie à quatre etc). Treatment includes separating the individuals as part of the treatment strategy , which often leads to resolution of the shared delusional beliefs in the secondary individual.
